Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 53358-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2019 
 
 
 
 
Global Research Alliances (Phase 3) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  AASLE  –  Asian and Australasian Society of Labour Economics 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ADR  –  Asian Development Review 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERCD  –  Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department  
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  Bambang Susantono, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Director General  Yasuyuki Sawada, Economic Research and Regional Cooperation 
Department (ERCD) 
   
Team leader  Lea Sumulong, Senior Economics Officer, ERCD 
Team members  Gemma Esther Estrada, Senior Economics Officer, ERCD 
Jesus Felipe, Advisor, ERCD 
Edimon Ginting, Deputy Director General, ERCD 
Mary Ann Magadia, Associate Operations Analyst, ERCD 
Joseph E. Zveglich, Jr., Deputy Chief Economist, ERCD

of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  involve  research  and 
development, policy advice, and capacity development on issues facing the developing member 
countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), in line with Strategy 2030’s operational 
priority  6:  Strengthening  governance  and  institutional  capacity.1 These  activities  will  entail 
partnerships  with  prominent  researchers  from  leading  national  and  international  research 
institutions on frontier development topics and methodologies. Collaboration activities will include 
enhancing the quality of ADB publications such as the Asian Development Review (ADR); co-
organizing prominent knowledge-sharing events such as Asian Development Conferences; and 
inviting speakers to share development ideas with ADB on cutting-edge, creative, and sustainable 
solutions to address DMCs’ development challenges. 
 
2.  Two previous TA projects focused on establishing global research alliances.2 The first was 
a pilot small-scale TA approved in April 2010 that supported  ADB’s collaboration with the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China and selected leading universities. The second TA, 
which will be completed in December 2019, was approved in December 2011 for an increased 
number of knowledge partners and covering a broader scope of collaboration. It supported a joint 
study on food security and established knowledge partnerships and networks with the Asian and 
Australasian  Society  of  Labour  Economics  (AASLE),  the  Philippine  Economic  Society,  the 
Indonesia Regional Science Association, and the Asian Workshop on Econometrics and Health 
Economics. It also brought an Asian perspective to global events such as the Emerging Markets 
Forum. 
 
3.  These partnerships helped enhance the profile and quality of ADB’s knowledge products 
and facilitated the efficient use of TA funds by identifying knowledge partners that share the 
research priorities of ADB’s Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD). 
This knowledge and support TA will seek to actively broaden the research areas covered by the 
partnerships and further expand the list of knowledge partners. A component of this TA was 
originally included in ERCD’s 2020 annual work program, but it was advanced to 2019 approval 
and combined with other similar TA components.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  DMCs  face  development  challenges  that  are  increasingly  becoming  more  complex, 
especially because of the impacts of the Fourth Industrial Revolution4 on jobs, the adverse effects 
of climate change, rapidly aging societies, and growing urbanization. DMC policy makers must 
effectively analyze these development challenges and recommend appropriate solutions. In most 
cases, however, domestic capabilities are inadequate to independently undertake empirical 
analyses and generate sound policies. DMC policy makers need a steady supply of quality 
evidence-based studies that address the complex questions they must deal with. Therefore, this 
TA aims to identify the pressing development issues faced by DMCs (particularly those belonging 
 
1  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
2  ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance for Establishing Global Research Alliances. Manila (TA 7514-REG); and ADB. 
2011. Technical Assistance for Establishing Global Research Alliances (Phase 2). Manila (TA 7972-REG). 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 29 October 2019. 
4  Technological advancements that define the Fourth Industrial Revolution include artificial intelligence, quantum 
computers, biotechnology, blockchain technology, three-dimensional printing, and new generation robotics.

2 
to groups A and B of ADB’s classification of DMCs) and offer innovative analyses that will help 
them devise policy reform measures suitable to their specific conditions.5  
 
5.  Under Strategy 2030, ADB will further strengthen its role as knowledge provider and 
convener of partnerships. ADB will work closely with DMCs to identify their needs and create the 
knowledge products and services most relevant to them. At the same time, ADB will collaborate 
with diverse partners and stakeholders within and outside Asia and the Pacific region to be able 
to present the most innovative solutions to DMCs’ development challenges. 
 
6.  ERCD, in line with Strategy 2030 priorities, identified its strategic research areas beginning 
from 2020 as (i) skills and jobs; (ii) macroeconomic resilience, including debt sustainability and 
fiscal policy; (iii) infrastructure deficits; (iv) urbanization; (v) gender equality and demographic 
changes; (vi) regional cooperation and integration; and (vii) disaster risk management and climate 
change. ERCD research will focus on these areas but will flexibly respond to emerging challenges 
and areas as requested by DMCs. To implement its research program, ERCD will strengthen its 
alliances with respected regional and global research institutions and development partners. Such 
alliances have proven helpful, particularly in (i) establishing a wider research network and 
improving access to a larger pool of talent, (ii) enhancing ADB’s capacity to produce innovative 
knowledge solutions, (iii) strengthening ADB’s role in convening policy dialogue to craft policy 
options, (iv) disseminating knowledge solutions more widely through its partners networks, and 
(v) ultimately further raising the profile of ADB as a knowledge institution. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: analytically sound and research-backed 
development policies formulated in DMCs.6 The TA will have the following outcome: policy 
discussions and formulation by DMC officials and the general research community supported.7 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output  1:  Findings  of  research  outputs  and  conferences  on  key  and  frontier 
development challenges reported to key DMC agencies and think tanks. ERCD will continue 
partnerships with leading research institutions from within and outside the region. The TA will 
support primary socioeconomic policy think tanks in DMCs that (i) share ERCD’s research 
interests, (ii) require capacity development, and (iii) have a direct link with DMC policy makers 
and planners. By leveraging DMC think tanks, ERCD hopes to contribute to the crafting of 
development policies, plans, and programs that are based on sound research evidence. The TA 
will consider collaborating with the Bangladesh Institute of Development Studies, the Centre for 
Economic  and  Social  Development  (Myanmar),  the  Economic  Policy  and  Competitiveness 
Research Center (Mongolia), the Center for Economic Development (Uzbekistan), the University 
of the South Pacific (Fiji but catering to the research needs of Pacific Island countries), and The 
National Research Institute (Papua New Guinea). 
 
 
5  ADB’s Classification of DMCs. https://www.adb.org/site/public-sector-financing/lending-policies. 
6  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific.  
Manila. Operational priority 6: strengthening governance and institutional capacity (footnote 1) and the aim of 
strengthening DMCs’ institutional capacities in addressing development issues. 
7  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
9.  The TA will also consider partnerships with regional academic associations such as the 
AASLE and the East Asian Economic Association and co-organize sessions during their annual 
conferences. These partnerships will allow ADB to benefit from exchanging research ideas with 
the associations’ network of economists in all economic fields for the East Asian Economic 
Association and in applied microeconomics (labor and human capital) for AASLE. Respected, 
internationally peer-reviewed economic journals will publish ERCD papers presented in the 
AASLE and the East Asian Economic Association conferences. 
 
10.  In addition, ERCD will continue to pursue its previous partnership with the Emerging 
Markets Forum, as long as the research areas remain complementary. The forum was created 
as a not-for-profit initiative to bring together high-level government and corporate leaders from 
around the world to engage in dialogue on the key economic, financial, and social issues facing 
emerging market economies. 
 
11.  The TA will also support collaboration with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation 
and Development on (i) studying leading development issues for selected ADB DMCs, (ii) co-
publishing a report on tax statistics, and (iii) undertaking research on disaster risk management. 
During implementation, the TA will identify other partners of high caliber to collaborate on other 
areas of research, such as (i) the role of behavioral economics in developing effective policy 
measures, (ii) using big data analytics, and (iii) further studying the impact of technology on jobs. 
 
12.  The TA will determine the DMC agencies that would most likely benefit from the TA’s 
knowledge  products  and  inform  the  agencies  of  the  research  findings  and  policy 
recommendations through mission consultations, workshops, and other outreach events. The TA 
will  proactively  undertake  dissemination  activities  for  these  knowledge  products  in  close 
coordination with the resident missions. 
 
13.  Output  2:  Asian  Development  Review  issues  published  and  effectively 
disseminated. The TA will support the continued publication of the ADR, which features research 
on development issues relevant to countries of Asia and the Pacific. Published by MIT Press, one 
of the world’s most prestigious academic publishers, the ADR produces high-quality empirical 
papers, survey articles, historical analyses, and policy-oriented work. The ADR’s journal ranking 
is on a gradual, upward, long-term trajectory and is more consistent than those of its peers such 
as the Asian Economic Papers, the Asian Economic Policy Review, the Asian Economic Journal, 
the Journal of Asian Economics, and the African Development Review.8 During 2016–2018, ADR 
special issues have covered topics on Asia’s structural transformation, the climate change 
challenge to the region’s development, urban and regional development, and potential growth of 
economies in the region. In view of the rapidly growing elderly population in many developing 
Asian economies, the next ADR special issue, targeted for publication in 2021, will focus on 
demographics and aging societies. 
 
14.  The ADR’s principal source of high-quality papers is the annual ADR conference, co-
chaired  by  a  guest  editor  who  invites  internationally  known  academicians  to  present  their 
proposed papers for the ADR. Other sources of high-quality papers are (i) the enhanced editorial 
system, which has attracted more unsolicited submissions; (ii) general invitations for paper 
submissions from events sponsored by other think tanks; and (iii) direct invitations to ADB staff 
and consultants, who have produced high-quality ADB economics and regional cooperation 
 
8  The rankings are based on Scimago Journal Ranking, which is a measure of scientific influence of a journal that 
accounts for both the number of citations received by a journal and the importance or prestige of the journals where 
such citations come from.

4 
working  papers  and  background  papers  for  the  ERCD  flagship  publications,  i.e.,  Asian 
Development Outlook, Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific, and Asian Economic Integration 
Report. 
 
15.  For 2020, the TA will initiate the annual Asian Development Conferences, which will be 
co-organized  with  well-established  regional  research  institutes.  ERCD  is  considering  co-
organizing the first Asian Development Conference in 2020 with the Korea Development Institute 
on the topics of economics of demography and population aging. The ADR will also source papers 
from invited speakers for the Distinguished Speakers Program, Asia Development Policy Lecture 
Series, Asia Thought Leadership Series, and regular ERCD seminars. These knowledge events 
(i) support the wider dissemination of revolutionary ideas and frontier research methodologies in 
addressing the region’s development challenges and (ii) provide a platform for leading analytical 
minds to share cutting-edge ideas on development. The TA will invite policy makers and young 
researchers working on frontier topics and methodologies to use these venues to present their 
research work. 
 
16.  ADR issues will be posted on the MIT Press and ADB websites and highlighted in the 
posting call for papers in major journal websites (e.g., Economics Research Network, Social 
Science Research Network, and Research Papers in Economics). The TA will distribute printed 
copies of the ADR through ADB’s resident missions to DMC economic planning agencies, libraries, 
and think tanks. The TA will develop a more aggressive marketing campaign in collaboration with 
ADB’s Department of Communications to enhance the visibility of the ADR to improve readership 
and paper submissions. 
 
17.  The TA will publish free electronic versions of the knowledge products generated under 
this TA and disclose them to the public, and will disseminate a limited number of printed copies 
to key stakeholders or upon demand only. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6 and TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  ADB will administer the TA. ERCD’s Office of the Chief Economist and Director General 
will  be  responsible  for  supervision  and  management  of  consultants,  procurement,  and 
accomplishment of the outputs. The TA will involve knowledge partnerships or cooperation 
arrangements with leading international and national research institutions within and outside the 
region. ERCD will refer to the database on research institutions with knowledge partnerships 
and/or cooperation arrangements with ADB, maintained by the Knowledge Advisory Services 
Center, to leverage previous successful partnerships. This TA will make best use of k-Nexus and 
coordinate with sector and thematic groups to minimize the risk of duplicating other departments’ 
past and ongoing efforts. The planned TA outputs will be entered into k-Nexus to build upon ADB’s 
accumulated knowledge and experience. Further, to ensure operational relevance of the TA, 
ERCD will implement a “One ADB” approach and rely on the country expertise, government 
relations, and other support of relevant operations departments in developing knowledge products 
and identifying potential knowledge partners. ADB will obtain a no-objection letter from the 
relevant DMC prior to conducting or financing any TA activity in the DMC.

5 
20.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

21.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time), its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions, and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended 
from time to time).9  
 
22.  Knowledge partnerships. ERCD will collaborate with knowledge partners to acquire 
cutting-edge and innovative development solutions for challenges faced by ADB DMCs. ERCD 
will  prepare  knowledge  partnership  agreements  or  cooperation  arrangements  during  TA 
implementation, once it has firmed up details of projects for collaboration and the corresponding 
suitable partners. ERCD will appoint a focal person to carry out integrity due diligence and 
financial management systems review (for necessary funds transfer) on the knowledge partners, 
in  consultation  with  the  relevant  units  as  identified  in  the  staff  instructions  on  knowledge 
partnerships and on cooperation arrangements and with relevant sector and thematic groups. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Global Research Alliances (Phase 3), and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
9  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Findings of research outputs and conferences on key and frontier development challenges 
reported to key DMC agencies and think tanks 
Production of knowledge products on key frontier development challenges 
1.1  Meet with DMC think tanks and corresponding ADB regional departments and discuss co-
authored research and/or co-organized knowledge events on mutually agreed topics based on 
common priorities of the DMCs and ERCD (every Q1, 2020–2022). 
1.2  Meet with regional knowledge partners and discuss co-authored research and/or co-organized 
events to ensure responsiveness to development issues that DMCs face (3 months before the 
event from 2020 to 2022). 
1.3  Process knowledge partnership agreements or cooperation arrangements (2 months before the 
event from 2020 to 2022). 
1.4  Conduct research and co-organize events (2020–2022). 
1.5  Complete research outputs (every December from 2020 to 2022). 
Dissemination activities 
1.6  Coordinate with relevant resident missions on disseminating the knowledge products to key 
agencies and/or think tanks in the DMCs (every Q1, 2020–2022). 
1.7  Conduct knowledge-sharing events or missions to relevant DMCs to present major findings and 
policy recommendations (every Q1, 2020–2022). 
2.  ADR issues published and effectively disseminated 
ADR workshops and ADC 
2.1  Meet with guest editors and discuss ADR thematic issues and potential contributors (every Q1, 
2020–2022). 
2.2  Meet with potential regional knowledge partners to co-organize the ADC (every Q1, 2020–2022). 
2.3  Hire consultants and resource persons (every quarter, 2020–2022). 
2.4  Conduct ADR workshops and ADC for the September ADR issues (every July, 2020–2022). 
2.5  Post ADR issues in the MIT Press and ADB websites (every March and September, 2021–2023). 
Distinguished Speakers Program, Asia Development Policy Lecture Series, Asia Thought 
Leadership Series, and ERCD seminars 
2.6  Undertake selection process of distinguished speakers, Asia development policy lecture 
speakers, Asia thought leadership speakers, and ERCD seminar speakers (every Q1, 2020–
2022). 
2.7  Engage speakers (2 months before the seminars).

8  Appendix 1 
2.8  Conduct  distinguished  speakers’,  Asia  development  policy  lecture  series,  and  Asia  thought 
leadership series talks (every Q3 or Q4, 2020–2022). 
2.9  Conduct ERCD seminars (once every quarter, 2020–2022). 
2.10  Process and finalize papers presented for ADR publication (every February and August, 2020–
2022). 
Dissemination activities 
2.11  Conduct dissemination activities, including highlighting ADR issues in the call for papers in major 
journal websites (e.g., Economics Research Network, Social Science Research Network, and 
Research Papers in Economics) (every September, 2020–2022). 
2.12  Coordinate with resident missions on the dissemination of ADR issues to DMC economic 
planning agencies, libraries, and think tanks (every April and October, 2020–2022). 
2.13  Disseminate printed copies of ADR issues to ADR editorial board members (every April and 
October, 2020–2022). 
Inputs 
ADB: $750,000 Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6) and $250,000 (TASF-other sources)

Not applicable

technical assistance.

Citations.

copies each and (2) the 27 partner libraries. 
d  The target figure of 6,000 is determined by the number of ADR downloads in 2019 as reported by MIT press. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.
